Award.AwardTitle: Dynamics of Large RNAs Studied Using Site-Directed Spin Labeling
Award.AbstractNarration:
In this award from the Chemistry of Life Processes Program in the Division of Chemistry, Dr. Peter Qin, from the University of Southern California, will investigate intrinsic dynamics in the nano- to microsecond regime of a large ribozyme using site-directed spin labeling. By monitoring nitroxide spin labels covalently attached to specific RNA sites with electron paramagnetic resonance spectroscopy, information on RNA dynamics will be obtained at various equilibrium states of wild type and mutant ribozymes. The studies aim to: (i) reveal sequence and structure elements that dictate intrinsic RNA dynamics, and (ii) correlate intrinsic dynamics to RNA folding and catalysis. The goal of the project is to advance fundamental understanding of the structure-dynamics-function relationship in RNA.

The broader impact of the proposed work stems from advancing experimental methods for probing biological systems, enhancing research infrastructure and resources, and providing knowledge that benefits the broader scientific community. The proposed work will contribute to student training at all levels, with emphasis on using a multidisciplinary approach and on promoting participation of members from under-represented groups (e.g. minority undergraduates from local primarily undergraduate institutions) in research. Examples from the Dr. Qin's research are incorporated into courses and education programs to propel the growth of the Chemistry Department and the University.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Outcomes Report

The major goals are to develop and apply a biophysical technique, site-directed spin labeling, to study dynamics and structures of large nucleic acid molecules, protein-nucleic acid complexes, and nucleic acid – small molecule complexes. As of the date of this report, this grant has supported work reported in 14 published papers. Major scientific developments and findings include:

(1) Develop new spin-labeling tools, including: (i) a new nitroxide spin label for monitoring motions of RNA and DNA; (ii) web-accessible computer program for modeling a wide range of spin labels attached to a variety of targets including protein, DNA, and RNA.

(2) Reveal that properties of RNA and DNA strand can modulate both the rate and ordering of motions of a structure module (i.e., a RNA or DNA duplex). These motional characteristics modulate sampling of the conformational space, consequently impacting folding of the nucleic acids and influencing their functions. The work yields fundamental insights on the relationship between sequence, dynamics, and structures in nucleic acids.

(3) Demonstrate the use of spin-labeling method to study interactions between a unique DNA structure, the G-quadruplex, and small molecules, including: (i) distinguishing different topological folds of G-quadruplexes with nitroxide spin-labels on DNA; and (ii) synthesizing novel nitroxide-tagged metal complexes for investigating the mode of small-molecule ligand binding to G-quadruplex and for sensing oxidative stress in cells.

(4) Establish spin-labeling investigations on the CRISPR-Cas9 system, a protein/RNA complex that acts as a sequence-specific nuclease and has been adapted for genome engineering in a wide range of organisms. Spin-labeling detection of conformational changes in the Cas9 protein and the target DNA have been demonstrated, and the work has provided information on structure and dynamics of the Cas9 complex at different stage of function, including RNA activation, target DNA unwinding and binding, and target DNA cleavage. This aids in deciphering the mechanisms of CRISPR-Cas9 target recognition and further developing CRISPR-based genome editing technology.

 

The Intellectual Merits of the work manifest as: (i) methodology developed for studying nucleic acids and their complexes with proteins and small molecules; and (ii) information gained on the structure-function relationship on these complexes, which advances our knowledge on biological functions and aids developments of biotechnology.

 

The Broader Impacts of the work include methodology and fundamental knowledge gained that benefit the broader scientific community, as well as human resource developments at all levels including minorities and pre-college students. The spin-labeling tools developed are now used by many other groups for investigating complex biological systems. The grant also supported work on two volumes of Methods in Enzymology that have described the use of state-of-the-art Electron Paramagnetic Resonance (EPR) methodologies for studying biological systems, which benefit both EPR practitioners and the broader scientific community. The grant has supported research training for students at all levels, including graduate, undergraduate and high-school students. Examples from the research have been incorporated into curriculum and public presentations. Together these contribute to training of a STEM workforce.
